questions.text: An anxious mother of a 3-day newborn, comes to you for a routine visit. While counselling about the weight gain pattern of the baby, you explain her that on an average the weight of the baby doubles by?
questions.solution: The weight of the baby doubles by 6 months.

questions.text: During a well child visit, a 6-month-old boy demonstrates clinical evidence of craniosynostosis. Which of the following is the most common type of craniosynostosis?
questions.solution:
• Craniosynostosis is premature closure of ≥ 1 cranial suture.
  • Scaphocephaly (Sagittal synostosis) is the most common type of craniosynostosis.

questions.text: Rachit, a 6 year's old child is seen at the school clinic for growth and development monitoring. Which of the following is characteristic of the rate of physical growth during this period?
questions.solution:
• During the Preschooler stage growth is very minimal. Weight gain is only 2kgs per year and Height is 6-8cm per year.
    • Most rapid growth and development- Infancy
    • Slow growth (decline in growth rate)- Toddler hood and Preschooler
    • Slower growth (slow and uniform growth rate)- School age
    • Rapid growth- Adolescence

choices.text: All individuals follow cephalo-caudal and proximo-distal
Different parts of the body grow at different rate
All individual follow standard growth rate
Rate and pattern of growth can be modified

questions.text: All the following are principles of growth and development except
questions.solution:
RULES OF GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT

  1. Growth and development occur in cephalo-caudal meaning development occurs throughout the body's axis. Example: the child must be able to lift the head before he is able to lift his chest. Proximo-distal is development that progresses from center of the body to the extremities. Example: a child first develops arm movement before fine-finger movement.
  2. Different parts of the body grow at different rate because some body tissue mature faster than the other such as the neurologic tissues peaks its growth during the first years of life while the genital tissue doesn't till puberty.
  3. G&D is predictable in the sequence which a child normally precedes such as motor skills and behavior.
  4. G&D can never be modified

choices.text: Breast Tanner II, Pubic Hair Tanner II
Breast Tanner II, Pubic Hair Tanner III
Breast Tanner III, Pubic Hair Tanner III
Breast Tanner IV, Pubic Hair Tanner IV

questions.text: A girl comes in to clinic for a well-child check. On exam, she has elevated breasts that extend beyond the borders of the areola but with no secondary mound and has pubic hair that is coarse and curly that extends laterally, covers pubis but spares medial thighs and does not extend across the pubis. What is her Tanner staging?
questions.solution: • This girl demonstrates Tanner stage III for both breast development and pubic hair distribution.

choices.text: Genitals Tanner I; Pubic hair Tanner I
Genitals Tanner II; Pubic hair Tanner II
Genitals Tanner II; Pubic hair Tanner III
Genitals Tanner III; Pubic hair Tanner II

questions.text: A 13 year old boy is presented to you by his father as he is worried that his child has not achieved pubertal development expected for his age. On examination, you see sparse straight lightly pigmented pubic hair, minimally enlarged penile size, and a small sized testis of about 2ml volume. What is the tanner staging you give to the pubertal development of the child?
What is the usual age by which the posterior fontanelle closes?
questions.solution:
• Posterior fontanelle either closed by birth or maximum by 2 months of age.
  • Normal size is < 0.5cm

questions.text: Spot diagnosis of following syndrome is
questions.solution:
APERT SYNDROME- remember the triad

  • Craniosynostosis/Brachycephaly
  • Mid face hypoplasia
  • Syndactyly

questions.text: A boy has now learnt to feed himself with spoon without spillage, can dress and undress himself with supervision, knows that he is a boy. These milestones are most likely developed between which age?
questions.solution:
• Feeding self without spillage is achieved by 15 months.
  • Can dress and undress self, knowing gender completely by 3 years.
  • Hence best possible answer here is 2 to 3 years.

IMPORTANT MILESTONES BETWEEN 2-3 YEARS OF AGE

GROSS MOTOR

  • Walking backwards- 2 years
  • Riding tricycle- 3 years
  • Standing on 1 foot- 3 years
  • Climbs stairs upwards and downwards (2 feet / step)- 2 years
  • Climbs upstairs with alternate feet- 3 years

FINE MOTOR

  • Making horizontal line- 2 years
  • Making a circle- 3 years
  • Tower of 6-7 cubes; Train without chimney- 2 years
  • Train with chimney- 2.5 years
  • Tower of 9-10 cubes; bridge of 3 cubes- 3 years

LANGUAGE

  • 2-word sentence- 2 years
  • Name, age, sex- 3 years

PERSONAL SOCIAL

  • Parallel paly- 2-3 years
  • Pretend play- 30 months
  • Undressing with support- 2 years
  • Dressing with support- 3 years
  • Handedness- 3 years

questions.text: Tanya had her first birthday party recently. During her party she was able to commando crawl with ease, but could not walk. She picked up all the gems from her cake. She could speak 2 words with meaning. She waved goodbye to her guests. Which are of Tanya's development is delayed?
questions.solution:
• Commando crawl (gross motor), picking up gems from cake- pincer grasp (fine motor), speaking 2 meaningful words (language), waving good bye (personal-social); all are achieved latest by 12 months. Hence, she has achieved all her milestones needed for her age.

MILESTONES AT 12 MONTHS

GROSS MOTOR

  • Stand without support
  • Walk with support

FINE MOTOR

  • Mature pincer grasp (holding like a pen)

PERSONAL SOCIAL

  • Plays a simple ball game

LANGUAGE

  • 1-2 meaningful words

choices.text: Inability to use sounds discriminately to parents

questions.text: Faiza is an 8-month-old girl who was born at term. She is seen in the pediatric outpatient department. She can roll over. She does not crawl. She can say 'dada', but says it to everyone not just her father. She reaches out and grasps objects with her left hand but not with her right, and puts objects in her mouth. She smiles, but is not able to wave bye-bye. Which aspect of her development is of most concern?
questions.solution:
• Waving bye comes at 9-12 months (option a)
  • Crawling begins at 8 months (option b)
  • Functional expressive language begins at 1 year (option c)
  • Preference for using her left hand at 8 months. Development of hand preference before 1 year of age is abnormal.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to you for routine assessment. He can walk with support, has a good pincer grasp, can play ball game, and can make cooing sound. Which type of development defect does the child have?
questions.solution:
• The child in the question has delay in language milestone as he is expected to speak atleast 1-2 meaningful words by 1 year of age. Rest all domains are developing normally.

Developmental dissociation:

  • Variation in attainment of milestones across ≥ 2 domains.

Developmental Regression:

  • Loss of previously acquired milestones. E.g., Rett syndrome

Developmental Deviation:

  • Sequence of attainment of milestone is not seen. E.g., Cerebral palsy

Global developmental delay:

  • Delayed achievement of milestones in all the domains

choices.text: In adolescence, it is a sign of insecurity
Needs treatment after 6 years of age

questions.text: False about thumb sucking among the following is
questions.solution:
• Thumb sucking is normal in infancy and toddlerhood, i.e., upto 4-5 years.
  • It is a behavioral problem, which may be self-soothing, i.e., a source of pleasure.
  • Persistent thumb sucking in adolescence is more common in girls and may be sign of insecurity. Persistent thumb sucking in older children can cause dental malalignment.
  • Treatment is not required till the age of 4-5 years. After that behavioral therapy in the form of positive reinforcement (giving reward for not sucking the thumb) is treatment of choice. Negative reinforcement (application of noxious agents to thumb) is second line of treatment.

questions.text: At what age does autism spectrum disorder usually become evident?
questions.solution:
• Autism spectrum disorder usually presents at this age because this is when language and social skills rapidly develop.
  • 12-24 months: Concerns may emerge at this stage but problems are less obvious and overdiagnosis is a problem.
  • Screening tools may be applied as early as 18 months of age.

choices.text: Absence of social smile by 6 months of age
Not using single words by 10 months of age
Not using 2-word phrases by 18 months of age
Lack of make-believe play by 12 months of age

questions.text: The parents of a 2-month-old girl are concerned that their child may be at risk for autism because her 18-month-old cousin was recently diagnosed with autism. Which of the following most accurately describes an early sign of autism?
questions.solution:
• Absence of a social smile and/or limited eye contact by 6 months of age may be an early sign of autism.
  • Additional early signs of autism include
    • Absence of babbling, pointing or other gestures by 12 months
    • Not using single words by 16 months or 2-word phrases by 24 months
    • Stereotypic use of language; lack of make-believe play by 18 months.

questions.text: With regard to the length of full-term neonate the upper to lower segment ratio is:

A 7 years old girl presents to the clinic for evaluation of short stature. He has no medical problems and his appetite is excellent. The father height is 170cm and the mother height is 160cm. The genetic target height for this child is:
questions.solution:
Mid parental height of a boy = Avg height of both parents + 6.5cm

Mid parental height of a girl = Avg height of both parents - 6.5cm

Hence, in the question

Avg. of parental height= (170+160)/2= 165

As she is a girl

MPH= 165 - 6.5= 158.5 cm

questions.text: During your morning round in general pediatric rotation, an intern ask you about the normal development of fine motor skills. In normal fine motor development. Which of the following should occur first?
questions.solution: • Children tend to be able to copy a shape 6 months before they can draw it. The usual developmental order of drawing shapes is: line, circle, cross, square, triangle.

questions.text: The age at which the infant achieves early head control with bobbing motion when pulled to sit is
questions.solution: Gross motor milestones in first 6 months

choices.text: Send genetic studies to find congenital disease
Send chromosomal array to find trisomy
Send to development pediatrician and occupational therapist for early intervention

questions.text: A baby boy born at 30 weeks of gestation is brought to you at 8 months of chronological age with complaint of not able to roll from prone to supine. What is the best next step of management?
questions.solution:
• Corrected gestational age = Chronological age- Preterm age

= 32 weeks - 10 weeks

= 22 weeks = 5.5 months

  • Hence, the corrected age of the child is 5.5 months and usual age for the prone to supine is 6 months.
  • Hence, the parents are to be reassured that child is normal for age.
  • Till 2 years of age, correction of gestational age has to be applied.
